Rubik’s Cube"}, "webPages": {"webSearchUrl": "https:\/\/www.bing.com\/search?q=what+was+the+first+product+to+have+its+barcode+scanned+at+purchase%3f+Rubik%e2%80%99s+Cube", "totalEstimatedMatches": 388000, "value": [{"id": "https:\/\/api.cognitive.microsoft.com\/api\/v7\/#WebPages.0", "name": "Barcode - Wikipedia", "url": "https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Barcode", "about": [{"name": "Barcode"}, {"name": "Barcode"}], "isFamilyFriendly": true, "displayUrl": "https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Barcode", "snippet": "As its first innovations, ... which allows users to view films about everyday objects by scanning the product's barcode with their iPhone camera. ...", "deepLinks": [{"name": "History", "url": "https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Barcode#History", "snippet": "In 1948 Bernard Silver, a graduate student at Drexel Institute of Technology in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, US overheard the president of the local food chain, Food Fair, asking one of the deans to research a system to automatically read product information during checkout. Silver told his friend Norman Joseph Woodland about the request, and they started working on a variety of systems. Their first working system used ultraviolet ink, but the ink faded too easily and was expensive. Convinced tha"}, {"name": "Industrial adoption", "url": "https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Barcode#Industrial_adoption", "snippet": "In 1981, the United States Department of Defense adopted the use of Code 39 for marking all products sold to the United States military. This system, Logistics Applications of Automated Marking and Reading Symbols, is still used by DoD and is widely viewed as the catalyst for widespread adoption of barcoding in industrial uses."}, {"name": "Use", "url": "https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Barcode#Use", "snippet": "Barcodes such as the UPC have become a ubiquitous element of modern civilization, as evidenced by their enthusiastic adoption by stores around the world; most items other than fresh produce from a grocery store now have UPC barcodes. This helps track items and also reduces instances of shoplifting involving price tag swapping, although shoplifters can now print their own barcodes. In addition, retail chain membership cards use barcodes to uniquely identify consumers, allowing for customized mark"}, {"name": "Symbologies", "url": "https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Barcode#Symbologies", "snippet": "The mapping between messages and barcodes is called a symbology. The specification of a symbology includes the encoding of the message into bars and spaces, any required start and stop markers, the size of the quiet zone required to be before and after the barcode, and the computation of a checksum. Linear symbologies can be classified mainly by two properties: Continuous vs. discrete"}, {"name": "Scanners (barcode readers)", "url": "https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Barcode#Scanners_(barcode_readers)", "snippet": "The earliest, and still the cheapest, barcode scanners are built from a fixed light and a single photosensor that is manually \"scrubbed\" across the barcode. Barcode scanners can be classified into three categories based on their connection to the computer. The older type is the RS-232 barcode scanner. Then, Steve Jobs suggested that they design and sell a single etched and silkscreened circuit"}, {"name": "Collectors' item", "url": "https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Apple_I#Collectors'_item", "snippet": "As of 2013, at least 63 Apple I computers have been confirmed to exist. T"}, {"name": "Clones and replicas", "url": "https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Apple_I#Clones_and_replicas", "snippet": "Several Apple I clones and replicas have been released in recent years. A software-compatible clone, produced using modern components, released in 2003 at a price of around $200. 2. PE6502: Created by Jason Putnam.
